result.markdown:
--- title: "Faster `rank(::QRPivoted)` function" description: "Benchmarking implementations of rank functions" author: - name: Ajinkya Kokandakar url: https://ajinkya-k.github.io/ orcid: 0000-0002-5300-3075 affiliation: University of Wisconsin, Madison affiliation-url: https://www.wisc.edu/ date: 11-28-2024 categories: [Julia, Linear Algebra] # self-defined categories citation: url: https://ajinkya-k.github.io/posts/2024-18-24-allocations-runtime/ draft: false # setting this to `true` will prevent your post from appearing on your listing page until you're ready! engine: julia julia: exeflags: - '-tauto' # - '--project' --- # Why am I writing about this? The current implementation of the rank method for pivoted QR decomposition in julia is slow and inefficient. The modified version proposed here improves run time by orders of magnitude. # Load necessary packages ::: {#2 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using LinearAlgebra using Chairmarks using PrettyChairmarks using Statistics import LinearAlgebra: rank using TidierPlots using DataFrames TidierPlots_set("plot_show", false) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` false ``` ::: ::: # Computing the rank from a pivoted QR decomposition Let's generate a $n \times n$ matrix say $A$ with rank $r$, by first generating a $n \times r$ matrix and then computing its outerproduct. ::: {#4 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} n = 100 r = 20 X = randn(n, r) outprod(X::Matrix) = X * X' A = X * X' π ``` ::: Now let's compute the pivoted QR factorization of A. ::: {#6 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Aqr = qr(A, ColumnNorm()); ``` ::: # Generate matrix of known rank The following function generates a $n \times m$ matrix of rank $r \leq \min(n, m)$. We will use this for benchmarking the implementations. This function was based on a stackoverflow answer [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/10149972). ::: {#8 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # Generate an `n × m` matrix of rank `r` function generatematrix(n::T, m::T, r::T) where {T<:Integer} A = randn(n, r) B = randn(m, r) return A * B' end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` generatematrix (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: # Computing the rank The current implmentation in the `julia` repo is as follows: ::: {#10 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function rank(A::QRPivoted; atol::Real=0, rtol::Real=min(size(A)...) * eps(real(float(one(eltype(A.Q))))) * iszero(atol)) m = min(size(A)...) m == 0 && return 0 tol = max(atol, rtol*abs(A.R[1,1])) return something(findfirst(i -> abs(A.R[i,i]) <= tol, 1:m), m+1) - 1 end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` rank (generic function with 16 methods) ``` ::: ::: The following implementation (`ranfast`) is orders of magnitude faster. See sections below for tests and benchmarks. ::: {#12 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function rankfast(A::QRPivoted; atol::Real=0, rtol::Real=min(size(A)...) * eps(real(float(one(eltype(A.Q))))) * iszero(atol)) m = min(size(A)...) m == 0 && return 0 rdiag = diag(getfield(A, :factors)) tol = max(atol, rtol*abs(rdiag[1])) return something(findfirst(abs.(rdiag) .<= tol), m+1) - 1 end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` rankfast (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: ::: {#14 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} rank(Aqr) == rankfast(Aqr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` true ``` ::: ::: ::: {#16 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} rankbench = @bs rank($Aqr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 459 samples with 1 evaluation.
 Range (min … max):   82.625 μs … 909.917 μs  ┊ GC (min … max):  0.00% … 82.97%
 Time  (median):     136.292 μs               ┊ GC (median):     0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   167.129 μs ±  83.371 μs  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  13.01% ± 25.16%

        ▁█ ▁▃▃                                                   
  ▃▃▄▆▆▇██▆███▄▅▆▃▃▃▃▂▂▂▂▁▁▁▁▁▂▄▂▂▂▄▂▄▃▃▃▃▃▃▃▃▂▃▃▃▃▂▂▃▂▁▂▂▁▁▁▁▂ ▃
  82.6 μs          Histogram: frequency by time          403 μs <

 Memory estimate: 1.68 MiB, allocs estimate: 67.
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#18 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} rankfastbench = @bs rankfast($Aqr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 2614 samples with 273 evaluations.
 Range (min … max):   87.758 ns …  24.794 μs  ┊ GC (min … max): 0.00% … 99.10%
 Time  (median):      97.377 ns               ┊ GC (median):    0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   131.324 ns ± 554.926 ns  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  1.68% ± 12.06%

  █▆▁▁                                                           
  ████▆▃▅▄▁▁▁▁▃▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▄▅▅▁▅▄▆ █
  87.8 ns       Histogram: log(frequency) by time        815 ns <

 Memory estimate: 1.05 KiB, allocs estimate: 6.
``` ::: ::: ::: # Varying the rank Now we generate matrices of size $1000 \times 100$, with ranks increasing from 1 to 100, to compare the two implementations. ::: {#20 .cell cache='true' execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} n = 100; m = 30 benchs = Vector{Chairmarks.Benchmark}() benchf = Vector{Chairmarks.Benchmark}() for r in 1:min(n,m) _qrA = qr(generatematrix(n, m, r), ColumnNorm()) _br = @be rank($_qrA) _brf = @be rankfast($_qrA) if (rank(_qrA) != rankfast(_qrA)) println("uh oh rank didnt match") else print(".") end push!(benchs, _br) push!(benchf, _brf) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` .............................. ``` ::: ::: ::: {#22 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} medslow = [median(bnc) for bnc in benchs] medfast = [median(bnc) for bnc in benchf] ``` ::: ::: {#24 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} xs = collect(1:min(m,n)) df = DataFrame( rank = xs, median_time = [b.time for b in medslow], median_time_fast = [b.time for b in medfast], medianbytes = [b.bytes for b in medslow], medianbytes_fast = [b.bytes for b in medfast]) ggplot(df) + geom_line( @aes(x = rank, y = median_time), color = "red" ) + geom_line( @aes(x = rank, y = median_time_fast), color = "blue" ) + labs( x = "rank", y = "runtime (in seconds, log scale)", title = "runtime of current (red) and faster (blue) method for $n x $m matrix" ) + scale_y_log10() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: ::: {#26 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} xs = collect(1:min(m,n)) ggplot(df) + geom_line( @aes(x = rank, y = medianbytes), color = "red" ) + geom_line( @aes(x = rank, y = medianbytes_fast), color = "blue" ) + labs(x = "rank", y = "memory allocated (in bytes, log scale)", title = "Median memory allocated of current (red) and faster (blue) method for $n x $m matrix") + scale_y_log10() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: # Why is the current implementaiton so slow? It's slow because it calls `Aqr.R` for every diagonal entry, which leads to computing the upper triangular matrix each time! If `min(n, m)` is large, that can mean recreating this matrix a lot of times! The code below demonstrates this. ::: {#28 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} A = generatematrix(10000, 100, 80); Aqr = qr(A, ColumnNorm()); ``` ::: ::: {#30 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @bs for i in 1:min(size(A)...) Aqr.R[i,i] end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 79 samples with 1 evaluation.
 Range (min … max):  523.791 μs … 10.242 ms  ┊ GC (min … max):  0.00% … 91.31%
 Time  (median):     802.542 μs              ┊ GC (median):     0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):     1.069 ms ±  1.172 ms  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  12.42% ± 24.73%

    ▇█▄▅  ▃                                                     
  ▇████████▆▃▁▃▅▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▃▁▃▁▁▁▁▁▃▁▃▁▃▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▃▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▃ ▁
  524 μs          Histogram: frequency by time         3.83 ms <

 Memory estimate: 7.64 MiB, allocs estimate: 503.
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#32 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @bs for i in 1:min(size(A)...) Aqr.factors[i,i] end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 3082 samples with 5 evaluations.

 Time  (median):     5.550 μs               ┊ GC (median):    0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   6.016 μs ±  17.884 μs  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  0.03% ±  1.77%

  ▄██▆▆▄▂▂▅▇▆▅▅▂▃▂▁ ▁                                         ▁
  ████████████████████▇▆▇█▇▆██▇▆▇▇▇▅█▇▆▅▅▅▄▆▇▇█▇▇▇▅▅▄▃▄▄▃▃▃▄▄ █
  5.19 μs      Histogram: log(frequency) by time      8.01 μs <

 Memory estimate: 4.77 KiB, allocs estimate: 203.
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#34 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @bs Aqr.R[1,1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 8019 samples with 1 evaluation.

 Time  (median):     7.000 μs              ┊ GC (median):    0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   9.371 μs ± 47.494 μs  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  0.21% ±  4.49%

   ▄           ▃▆█▅▂                                          
  ▄█▄▂▂▁▁▁▁▁▂▂▅█████▇▅▄▄▄▃▃▃▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▁▁▁▂▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ ▂
  3.79 μs        Histogram: frequency by time        15.6 μs <

 Memory estimate: 78.33 KiB, allocs estimate: 8.
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#36 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @bs Aqr.factors[1,1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 3405 samples with 899 evaluations.
 Range (min … max):  27.623 ns …  4.305 μs  ┊ GC (min … max): 0.00% … 98.71%
 Time  (median):     28.133 ns              ┊ GC (median):    0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   30.532 ns ± 73.325 ns  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  0.03% ±  1.69%

  ▅█▇▂▅▄▂ ▁  ▂▆▃                                              ▁
  ███████▇█▆████▇▆██▆▄▆▇▆▆▇▇▇▅▆▆▅▅▆▆▄▇▅▅▆▄▆▅▅▄▄▅▄▃▃▆▆▃▄▄▆▄▆▄▃ █
  27.6 ns      Histogram: log(frequency) by time      39.9 ns <

 Memory estimate: 16.124582869855395 bytes, allocs estimate: 1.
``` ::: ::: ::: # Alloc can get bad for large matrices! If the matrix is large (even if the rank is small), the current method allocates too much! See example below. ::: {#38 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Mqr = qr(generatematrix(1000, 100, 50), ColumnNorm()); ``` ::: The current implementation allocated ~400 megabytes and takes on the order of 100 ms to run! ::: {#40 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @bs rank($Mqr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 169 samples with 1 evaluation.
 Range (min … max):  198.292 μs …   5.292 ms  ┊ GC (min … max): 0.00% … 92.62%
 Time  (median):     413.875 μs               ┊ GC (median):    0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   568.746 μs ± 590.756 μs  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  8.51% ± 24.13%

      ▅▇█▁                                                       
  ▄▃▃▄████▄▅▁▃▁▂▁▁▁▂▁▁▁▁▁▁▃▁▃▂▁▂▁▂▂▁▂▁▁▃▃▂▁▁▁▂▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▂▁▁▁▁▁▁▂ ▂
  198 μs           Histogram: frequency by time         2.35 ms <

 Memory estimate: 3.97 MiB, allocs estimate: 157.
``` ::: ::: ::: The faster method only allocates ~10 kilobytes and the runtime is in μs!! ::: {#42 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @bs rankfast($Mqr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
Chairmarks.Benchmark: 3425 samples with 154 evaluations.

 Time  (median):     110.656 ns              ┊ GC (median):    0.00%
 Time  (mean ± σ):   169.068 ns ±  1.275 μs  ┊ GC (mean ± σ):  0.23% ±  4.76%

``` ::: ::: :::
